author: NEW YORK DAILY NEWS
title: Activists fined if they harass horse carriage drivers: judge
text:
A Manhattan judge said ‘whoa’ on Tuesday to anti-horse carriage activists — ordering them to quit nagging tourists and carriage drivers in Central Park or wind up in jail.
In a wry and articulate ruling, state Supreme Court Justice Arthur Engoron decided that free speech and buggy rides can go together like, well, you know the tune.
“Horses and carriages have gone together since time immemorial, but human beings are still grappling, or may be just beginning to grapple, fully with the implications,” Engoron writes.
In laying out his decision, the droll jurist quotes a certain song made famous by Frank Sinatra and cites his participation in anti-Vietnam war protests.
Central Park horse carriage group seeks to rein in protesters 
The “free speech absolutist” is OK with speaking one’s mind, he writes, but harassing hapless tourists taking in the city from atop a buggy is certainly out of bounds.
The activists believe the horses are mistreated and want to put a stop to the tradition.
But their “relentless, in-your-face yelling at families with children, and at elderly couples that look like they are from Des Moines or Dubuque” crosses the line, according to Engoron.
Front page of the New York Daily News for Dec. 10, 2016: LET US MAKE HAY FOR HOLIDAYS (New York Daily News) “The horse carriage trade is a lawful business and an iconic part of the Manhattan landscape,” he adds.
Activists harass tourists riding horse drawn-carriages in NYC 
Carriage operators sued animal-rights groups, including New Yorkers for Clean Livable and Safe Streets, asking that they be barred from disrupting business.
The judge cites videos submitted to the court that show “in-your-face shouting; yelling at patrons sitting in carriages; thrusting literature at people who have declined it; and accosting people and then persisting after it is clear they do not wish further involvement.”
He believes the true victims are the “riders who are caught in the middle and who probably thought that, worst case scenario, they would be subject to a horse urinating or defecating in their presence.”
Protesters are barred from touching, pushing or shoving riders, horses or their drivers. They also must refrain from physically blocking, impeding or obstructing any persons from seeking or taking... a lawful horse-carriage ride” or face jail time and fines.
SEE IT: Animal rights activist shoves NYC horse carriage driver 
“Make no mistake: the content of the speech is not at issue here, the manner of delivery is,” Engoron writes.
